title: IT: idiosyncratic typeface
content:
What do you think is an "idiosyncratic typeface"?   
   
Please don`t consider the term just in a typographic way,   
but also, especially, under a linguistic & anthropological   
point of view.   
   
Thanks for helping me in my research.   
AS
author: as8

comments.content:
This seems sort of vague. Or maybe it's that there's too many of them these days to pick out just a few?   
   
I guess when you say "idiosyncratic" you have to explain if you mean with respect to typographic tradition (which would mean like most of the Emigre library for example), or maybe instead with respect with the functional needs of type - I'm talking about the need for each glyph to fit with all the others in the font. So for example NotCaslon would qualify for the first but not the second, since its glyphs are well-integrated.   
   
Dunno...   
   
hhp
IT: any of its characters may be identified as belonging to only one typeface.

Just to introduce a bit of me & my question,   
I am working on my MA-Thesis in Graphic Design:   
a typeface based on Ernest Hemingway's "The Old Man & the Sea" style/content.   
(An interpretation of) The harsh and beautiful relation between literature & typography.   
If our field is to advance, we must, without displacing creativity and aesthetics,   
make sure our terminology is clear.   
This is nice & useful thing for me to read people's ways of distinguishing the theme.   
Spiekermann's reply was great.   
Right now, I'm working sulle minuscole (on the lower cases);   
I'm busy now working on the font on computer, I'm using FontLab for the first time,   
it is a super cool software. I'm gonna put the 'IT' contributions in my thesis.   
IT is also the Internet code for Italy, quite funny.   
Thank you for the adjective "elaborate", Yves Peters, that makes me hopeful;   
smart line mr Nick Shinn; mr Papazian's, precisely, with respect with the functional   
needs of type, just merci!   
To the next one.

Perhaps I am looking at it backwards. I am seeing a type with idiosyncracies. To me, this is a type with quirks, a type with glyphs or parts of glyphs which break either the patterrn of form seemingly developed in the rest of the font or even different from the "norm" of all typefaces we know. It is like seeing a double-take in film�you are not quite sure that what you saw was "really" what you saw so you look again to confirm it.   
When I first saw text set in "The Mix," I had to look twice to see if had only partial serifs. On second viewing, it was clear to me that Luc had a very deliberate system going and today I would not say The Mix was idiosyncratic. Even joke fonts like "Ransomnote" (which has a different font for each character) is not idiosyncratic because it is consistent in its inconsistency. Rotis, on the other hand, drives me crazy with its lower case "e"�I would call Rotis idiosyncratic but most people wouldn't even notice.   
   
Chris L

I don't know. I am thinking along the lines of Nick in regards   
to the macro/micro nature of a typeface. Some designers most   
certainly have idiosyncracies that come through in their type   
designs. Sometimes not easy to pinpoint, more of a feel I think.   
   
kris.

Mr. Chris Lozos, I appreciate your line -- about "seeing a double-take in film," that you are not quite sure that what you saw was "really" what you saw so you look again to confirm it -- because it reminds me to my dominant intention, which is to encourage the watcher looking two times.   
Thought I`m designig a text letter type based on Roman Capital proportions (Uc) & Gill Sans' (lc) applied within a sailing-symbolic-grid, hem, yes, ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051144im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif), well, that is what triggered my question.   
   
Mr. Kris Sowersby, micro-macro fits very well with the biology of the man, his brain, his soul, the ecosystem and so on, it is a salient word (concept) quoted there, grazie.

Ciao, I'd like to spur you on joinin this discussion,   
I'm gonna put the 'IT' contributions in my graduation thesis;   
the form will be the following:   
   
Giangiorgio Fuga, ITALY.   
 [http://www.giofuga.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516051144/http:/www.giofuga.com/)  
Non ha nulla a vedere con i caratteri tipografici! Ma tipologia comportamentale, esempio:   
Le onde generazionali sono il risultato del carattere idiosincratico della produzione di beni   
fondati sulla cultura: la coppia spazio/tempo ha una forza...
